newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Shell plans doubling Nigeria oil output.
newsitem.headline: Shell plans doubling Nigeria oil output.

text.p: Shell's budget-strapped Nigerian oil operations could easily double output from already discovered crude reserves if government funding problems are resolved, the company's managing director in the country, Brian Anderson, said.
Shell's Nigerian joint venture, now producing 930,000 barrels per day (bpd), is aiming for a new plateau of at least two million bpd by 2010, Anderson told reporters in Lagos.
"We're aiming at two million-plus by 2010 but that excludes the new deepwater operations," he said.
Shell currently pumps just under half the country's two million bpd in partnership with state Nigerian National Petroleum Corp.
Anderson said the government's failure to meet its funding obligations through a 55 percent share in the Shell joint venture had hobbled crude output over the past couple of years.
Shell expects the military government to embark on a phased five-year sale of the oil sector which would take financing out of state hands.
Arrears to all joint venture operators in Nigeria now amounted to the equivalent of $500 million in total in dollar and naira payments, Anderson said.
Shell Petroleum Development Co of Nigeria underspent its budget last year and has been promised less than it asked for in 1996.

"Although we had an approved budget of just of $1.5 billion, we ended spending just over a billion," Anderson said. "We wanted to make the point that we can't go on investing if they don't pay their share."
The company proposed a $1.63 billion budget for this year but expects the joint venture to get just $1.2 billion.
It was aiming for a $1.96 billion budget next year, rising to over $2 billion in 1998.
To fill the gap before the expected government oil sector sale, Anderson said Shell Nigeria was considering raising extra capital on the domestic market.
He said he did not expect the government to take a hard line on new orders from Oil Minister Dan Etete threatening expropriation of undeveloped oilfields licensed to Shell to 2025.
"I think the government will be cautious about this. It would be a bad signal when you're trying to sell equity. We have an acreage agreement and we expect it to be honoured."
Anderson said Shell's Nigerian operations continued to be hit occasionally by sabotage following an oilworkers' strike in 1994 which cut production.
"Sabotage continues all the time. Thirty percent of leaks are caused by sabotage."
Anderson said he closed down Shell's dry land operations to protect company staff in Nigeria during the strike in support of jailed presidential candidate Moshood Abiola.
